Award.AwardTitle: G8 Initiative: Sustainable Manufacturing of Solution-Processed Devices on Flexible Substrates Using Nanohybrid Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This NSF award to Rutgers University New Brunswick funds U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by the G8 Research Councils Initiative. This is a pilot collaboration among the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Canadian National Sciences and Engineering Research Council (NSERC), the French Agence Nationale de la Recherche (ANR), the German Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG), the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS), the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (RFBR),and the United Kingdom Research Councils (RCUK), supporting collaborative research projects selected on a competitive basis that are comprised of researchers from at least three of the partner countries.

This multi-national collaboration--Methods for Materials-efficient Manufacturing (M3)-- will perform research on polymer-nanoparticle hybrid materials for sustainable production of advanced technology devices. The M3 team includes the University of Massachusetts Amherst and Rutgers University (U.S.), Tohoku University and the University of Tokyo (Japan), and Institut de Chimie de la Matière condensée de Bordeaux and the UMR CNRS Environnement, Ville, Société (France). The M3 research program focuses on solution-based processing of devices, device layers, components and functional materials on a roll-to-roll production platform, in which hybrid materials containing both polymers and nanoparticles are used to generate functional devices on flexible substrates. One technical goal for the project is development of solution-coatable high dielectric constant device layers comprised of polymer/nanoparticle composites; these layers are the active components of working devices, and progress in this field will advance efficient roll-to-roll flexible device production. A second technical goal is the use of polymer/nanoparticle solutions to form highly transparent emissive nanocomposite films containing optically active nanoparticles, including rare-earth dopes phosphors, as the functional component. U.S. research activities focus on developing the polymer hybrid materials and roll-to-roll processing methods (UMass Amherst), and synthesizing and characterizing the optically active composites (Rutgers).

The outcomes from this multinational research project will lead to more materials-efficient and sustainable manufacturing of materials and devices for applications such as energy conversion and storage, flexible electronics and displays, and optoelectronics. Compared to conventional batch vacuum and deposition processes, the solution-based roll-to-roll process can afford lower cost, less waste and significantly lower energy inputs. When combined with innovations in the materials used in the coating process for device fabrication, it is expected that the resultant process will involve fewer steps, no batch changes, commodity-priced materials, lower process temperatures, and drastically lower water usage, thereby reducing direct energy consumption.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major goals of the project included the recruitment and training of a graduate student to perform scientific research, conduct collaborative research, and effectively distribute relevant results and findings to the community. Training was conducted within context of two separate, but fundamentally related research topics. The first topic was the study on the effects of low temperature heat treatment on the optical brightness and physical characteristics of sodium yttrium fluoride doped with ytterbium and erbium. The second was a collaborative research effort between Rutgers University and the University of Massachusetts Amherst to demonstrate refractive index matching as a means of improving the optical brightness and transmittance of polymer composites containing luminescent rare earth particles, lanthanum fluoride doped with ytterbium and erbium (La0.92Yb0.075Er0.005F3), that absorb and emit light at the telecommunication wavelengths (980 nm and 1550 nm, respectively).

Maximum transmittance and optical brightness for the polymer composites containing La0.92Yb0.075Er0.005F3 were achieved when the refractive index of the polymer matrix matched that of the La0.92Yb0.075Er0.005F3. The improved optical brightness and transmittance has been attributed to decreased scattering at the interface(s) between the La0.92Yb0.075Er0.005F3 particles and the surrounding, refractive index tuned polymer matrix. Light scattering increases when the difference in the refractive indices of the La0.92Yb0.075Er0.005F3 and the polymer matrix increases. Changes in optical brightness and transmittance were not due to fundamental changes in the electronic environment of the ytterbium and erbium ions. The composites successfully incorporated particles greater than 100 nm in size. The choice to utilize large particles, over nanoparticles, was driven by the fact that much greater amount of particles can be loaded into the polymer. Increased loading increases the maximum optical brightness that can be achieved.

Optically bright, transmissive polymer composites would enable the production of flexible, inexpensive optical devices. Devices such as displays, authentication technologies, optical amplifiers, photonic circuits, and biophotonics among others would be more inexpensive and ecologically friendly than the alternative contemporary products that they would replace (e.g., single crystal lenses, fiber lasers, and OLEDs). The findings and processes developed in the collaborative research effort would form a basis for sustainable, roll to roll polymer composite technologies. Roll to roll allows for simple, mass production of components that would benefit from economies of scale and decreased ecological footprint. Finally, broadband information transmission is more feasible with the refractive index matching methodology. This would be accomplished by incorporating a mixture of luminescent particles individually doped with different ions that emit at different telecommunication wavelengths; the rare earth ions would not electronically interact with each other as they are in separate, but chemically same particles. Refractive index matching would be viable for a broadband system as the host material containing the rare earth ions are the same. As such, increased access to the internet due to decreasing costs associated with access, infrastructure expansion, and maintenance allows for a more informed, active, and aware citizenry.
